channel.title: 华尔街日报热门
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: The U.S. won an appeal against a U.K. court's decision to bar the extradition of Julian Assange, clearing a hurdle in its pursuit of the WikiLeaks founder https://t.co/2s3Pnx0DGh
From @WSJopinion: A new poll from Gallup confirms that the American people still have more faith in capitalism than they do in socialism https://t.co/HDnyZoT5cE

GE, Union Pacific and other large employers have suspended Covid-19 vaccine requirements for workers after a court ruling blocked the Biden administration's mandate for federal contractors https://t.co/nLsYx38XsP

The U.S. plans to ban American investment in Chinese AI company SenseTime and is looking to block SMIC, China's largest chip maker, from buying U.S. manufacturing tools, people familiar with the matter said https://t.co/9wt7VA8466
“If it’s gone, it’s a big deal.” Researchers want to know if one of the four main influenza strains that infect humans has disappeared https://t.co/IjvUV2j3Kf
Breaking: Actor Jussie Smollett was found guilty of lying to police when he reported being the victim of a hate crime near his Chicago apartment in 2019 https://t.co/krRkbVXm4e
An appeals court rejected former President Trump's bid to block the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 riot from gaining access to records from his presidency https://t.co/hik04N1StN

New York City lawmakers are set to vote on a bill that would let more than 800,000 residents who aren’t U.S. citizens vote in local elections, potentially becoming the largest city in the U.S. to do so https://t.co/A4ozeJbp6J
The holiday shopping season makes us prime targets for cybercriminals. Here’s how to avoid some of the most popular scams plus other tips for online safety https://t.co/YsTLizQUx4
The Senate approved legislation aimed at nullifying President Biden’s vaccine-or-test mandate for private employers https://t.co/IMYfuxAqAl
Starbucks baristas in Buffalo, N.Y. voted to form the first labor union at one the coffee giant’s U.S. cafes in the company’s 50-year history https://t.co/gGC1tGneTZ

Half of Americans support President Biden’s Covid-19 vaccine requirements for private-sector employers, and a slim majority backs other state and local mandates, a new Wall Street Journal poll finds https://t.co/Xe4i4aux5L
New York Attorney General Letitia James said she is ending her bid for governor and will seek another term in her current office https://t.co/hIzDImGOXn

Rupert Murdoch purchased a 340,000-acre Montana cattle ranch from the Koch family for roughly $200 million, making it the largest ranch sale in state history, people with knowledge of the deal said https://t.co/YMzg1FftKq

In a significant rebuke, the Senate approved legislation to nullify President Biden’s Covid-19 vaccine-or-test mandate for private employers, with two Democratic senators voting with Republicans #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/4z6bOsMPHD
Amazon was fined $1.3 billion by Italian regulators for favoring sellers that use its logistics services. The company faces a similar probe by the EU. https://t.co/cHmyVMclQB
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/5xQPDPcm8q https://t.co/V3wUTya2d0

Photos entered into evidence at Ghislaine Maxwell’s sex-trafficking trial include pictures of her kissing and hugging Jeffrey Epstein and giving him a foot rub on a private jet, providing a glimpse into how close the two were, prosecutors say https://t.co/kHQEhFPg2r
Japan's restless seniors try team videogaming. “It’s better than having nothing to do at home and watching TV." https://t.co/IMsstI3vyD
The Turkish lira has plummeted, but so far the world’s biggest emerging markets have avoided contagion, explains @ahirtens #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/OXgNaH18ky
The U.K. and Canada have joined a widening diplomatic boycott of the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing https://t.co/uSq6csOS1O

From @WSJopinion: “My generation will rely on the future economic growth spurred by investments made today. We want a country that values hard work and doesn’t take away more of our money—especially money we don’t even have.” https://t.co/mvYZtaS4im

The Senate is expected to pass legislation aimed at nullifying President Biden’s vaccine-or-test mandate for private employers, a move that would mark a significant bipartisan rebuke of the president https://t.co/BQPA3gUTZU
Due to the Amazon cloud outage, a couple had to "manually" feed their cats "like in ancient times" https://t.co/WKAyDWtItM

From @WSJopinion: By pretending that the police are a bigger threat to society than the criminals, progressive policies are making the country demonstrably less safe than it’s been in decades, writes @jasonrileywsj https://t.co/1GG1jd75y4

Biden convenes a summit of democracies this week, but in the background potential crises are unfolding: a potential Russian invasion of Ukraine, continuing Chinese pressure on Taiwan and the potential collapse of Iran nuclear talks, writes @GeraldFSeib https://t.co/bZJKsKAg1h
Turkey's embattled economy could get worse before it gets better, investors and economists fear https://t.co/MiVevzZZ8a
Epidemiologists believe Singapore is the first country to adopt a policy of withdrawing coverage of Covid-19 medical costs specifically for those who choose to go unvaccinated https://t.co/Zjc8pRWq13
Omicron was able to elude two doses of the Covid-19 vaccine from Pfizer and BioNTech in initial lab testing, but three doses neutralized the variant, the companies said https://t.co/efJcH1q2Lx
One container ship waited nearly two months to dock at port. Here’s what the delay meant for small businesses with chess sets, holiday boots and other products stuck on board. https://t.co/bomQKQxD5g
Australia is joining the U.S. in a diplomatic boycott of the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing https://t.co/gCRcmaUwMw
The United Arab Emirates is shifting to a 4½-day workweek that will start Monday and end on Friday at noon https://t.co/sgz89dNcdr
A U.S. judge on Tuesday blocked the Biden administration’s Covid-19 vaccine mandate for employees of federal contractors https://t.co/FBUE9wljht

U.S. voters are pessimistic about the economy and short on confidence in President Biden’s leadership, a new WSJ Poll finds, a warning for Democrats entering a midterm election year https://t.co/mtDVlcpYEQ

Actor Laura Dern, known for her roles in "Big Little Lies," "Little Women" and "Marriage Story," wakes up at 6:30 a.m. and makes an effort to not pick up her phone first thing. She meditates for a few minutes instead. https://t.co/R9wRqQCp8p
Rohingya refugees sued Facebook parent Meta Platforms for $150 billion, alleging the social-media platform perpetuated the genocide against the Muslim ethnic group in Myanmar https://t.co/3coTVUIHTj
Amazon Web Services, the cloud-computing unit of Amazon, appeared to be down for thousands of users Tuesday morning https://t.co/GYnmAfn1OO

CNN won’t pay anchor Chris Cuomo a severance after firing him amid revelations that he helped his brother, Andrew Cuomo, respond to allegations of sexual harassment, the network’s president told employees https://t.co/vvkpMSeilA

Nobuo Matsubara still remembers being told in January 1942 that his brother, a Japanese navy ensign, had been killed in the attack on Pearl Harbor. It wasn’t true. But under the values of the time, the truth was even worse https://t.co/pjp3LmTax7

From @WSJopinion: History can be cruel to candidates for President who lose, but Bob Dole’s contributions to American life far exceeded his failed campaigns for the White House https://t.co/MJM68exDPl
The governor of Hawaii declared a state of emergency as pounding rainfall hits the tropical islands, causing flooding and power outages in some places https://t.co/zJ3df6pliB
Big wage increases are in store for next year. A new report shows companies budgeting the most for raises since 2008. https://t.co/7crjPLbYE2
U.S. Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg speaks with WSJ’s @catherine_lucey at #WSJCEOCouncil https://t.co/DJ68z02nZG
From @WSJopinion: New York Mayor Bill de Blasio’s vaccine mandate for all workers is an infringement on liberty and a strike against the city, not the virus. https://t.co/6SXhsV218I

Evergrande didn’t make payments due on some U.S. dollar bonds before a final deadline expired Monday, people familiar with the matter said, potentially setting the stage for a massive default and one of the country’s largest-ever debt restructurings https://t.co/ZBPSAPLVdl

“Honestly, I would just can this whole bill.” Tesla CEO Elon Musk criticized federal efforts meant to spur electric-vehicle adoption, including a bill that would boost incentives for buying battery-powered cars #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/yeiEt1CcZt
Disappearing court documents. Restricted access to data on ships and supplies. China closes off details about what’s happening inside the country. https://t.co/qzYQo1pM83

Indian and Russian officials rejected American pressure to downgrade their close defense ties as the two countries’ leaders met in New Delhi and agreed to extend military technical cooperation for another decade https://t.co/Tv5I3uxMiQ

Saudi Arabia is running out of the ammunition to defend against drone and missile attacks from the Houthi rebels in Yemen, and is appealing to the U.S. and its Gulf and European allies for a resupply https://t.co/vabKKjCkKg
Watch: Investors are pouring money into the meme-based cryptocurrency Shiba Inu Coin, WSJ retail investing reporter Caitlin McCabe explains why https://t.co/7UE5m3EZvt
